elements.content: The preparation, X-ray crystallography, and magnetic investigation of the compounds [Co(H2O)2(phda)] n (1), [Co(phda)] n (2), and [Co(chda)] n (3) [H2phda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid and H2chda = 1,1-cyclohexanediacetic acid] are described herein. The cobalt atoms in this series are six- (1) and four-coordinated (2 and 3) in distorted octahedral (CoO6) and tetrahedral (CoO4) environments. The structures of 1−3 consists of rectangular-grids which are built up by sheets of cobalt atoms linked through anti-syn carboxylate bridges, giving rise to either a three-dimensional structure across the phenyl ring (1 and 2) or to regularly stacked layers with the cyclohexyl groups acting as organic separators (3). The magnetic properties of 1−3 were investigated as a function of the temperature and the magnetic field. Ferromagnetic coupling between the six-coordinate cobalt(II) ions across the anti-syn carboxylate bridge occurs in 1 (J = +1.2 cm−1) whereas antiferromagnetic coupling among the tetrahedral cobalt(II) centers within the sheets is observed in 2 and 3 [J = −1.63 (2) and −1.70 cm−1 (3)] together with a spin-canted structure in 3 giving rise a long-range magnetic ordering (T c = 7.5 K).

elements.content:
(4,4) Layered or pillared-layered Co(II)-complexes demonstrated that small structural modifications may cause important differences in the magnetic behavior of similar systems.

Introduction

Polynuclear compounds of high-spin cobalt(II) ions bridged by carboxylate groups exhibit different magnetic behaviors depending on the bridging mode of the carboxylate and on its coordination number. In general, significant antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers are mediated by the carboxylate bridge in the syn-syn and anti-anti coordination modes, whereas weak magnetic interactions either ferro- or antiferromagnetic in nature are observed across the anti-syn bridging mode. Other bridges such as the hydroxo- or carboxylate-oxo have been also studied, and these works have shown that the nature of the d7−d7 exchange coupling is mainly governed by the angle at the bridging oxygen atom (θ) being antiferromagnetic for θ near 180° and either antiferro- or ferromagnetic when θ is close to 90°.

(4,4) Layered or pillared-layered Co(II)-complexes demonstrated that small structural modifications may cause important differences in the magnetic behavior of similar systems.

Introduction

Polynuclear compounds of high-spin cobalt(II) ions bridged by carboxylate groups exhibit different magnetic behaviors depending on the bridging mode of the carboxylate and on its coordination number. In general, significant antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers are mediated by the carboxylate bridge in the syn-syn and anti-anti coordination modes, whereas weak magnetic interactions either ferro- or antiferromagnetic in nature are observed across the anti-syn bridging mode. Other bridges such as the hydroxo- or carboxylate-oxo have been also studied, and these works have shown that the nature of the d7-d7 exchange coupling is mainly governed by the angle at the bridging oxygen atom (θ) being antiferromagnetic for θ near 180° and either antiferro- or ferromagnetic when θ is close to 90°.

elements.content: Correlations between the magnetic properties of molecule-based solids and their structure together with the nature of the chemical bond are useful for the design of new materials. In this respect, recent results on metal organic frameworks (MOFs) constituted by organic−inorganic magnetic layers have shown that it is possible to vary chemically the interlayer spacing. Focusing on two-dimensional (2D) magnetic systems where the metal centers are bridged by carboxylate groups, it is well known that the ferro- or antiferromagnetic nature of the intralayer magnetic coupling is strongly dependent on the conformation of the M−O−C−O−M unit, as mentioned above. The presence of magnetic anisotropy, as in the case of six-coordinated high-spin cobal(II), enhances the interest in these materials from a magnetic point of view. Thinking of the preparation of functional materials with applications in gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, and magnetic devices, the use of polycarboxylic acids with aromatic rings seems to be a good choice given their versatility as ligands and their remarkable ability to afford extended networks. Most of the work has been carried out with rigid polycarboxylate ligands such as those derived from the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acids. Studies of complex formation between transition metal ions and more flexible polycarboxylate ligands containing rings such as the deprotonated forms of the 1,4-phenylenediacetic (H2phda) or 1,1-cyclohexanediacetic (H2chda) acids are not so common.

Focusing on two-dimensional (2D) magnetic systems where the metal centers are bridged by carboxylate groups, it is well known that the ferro- or antiferromagnetic nature of the intralayer magnetic coupling is strongly dependent on the conformation of the M-O-C-O-M unit, as mentioned above. The presence of magnetic anisotropy, as in the case of six-coordinated high-spin cobal(II), enhances the interest in these materials from a magnetic point of view. Most of the work has been carried out with rigid polycarboxylate ligands such as those derived from the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acids. Studies of complex formation between transition metal ions and more flexible polycarboxylate ligands containing rings such as the deprotonated forms of the 1,4-phenylenediacetic (H2phda) or 1,1-cyclohexanediacetic (H2chda) acids are not so common.

elements.content: In this work we present the first examples of MOFs resulting from the assembly of cobalt(II) ions with the phda2− and chda2− ligands, namely, [Co(H2O)2(phda)] n (1), [Co(phda)] n (2), and [Co(chda)] n (3). 1 and 2 are three-dimensional (3D) compounds whereas 3 is a two-dimensional (2D) network. Curiously, six- (1) and four-coordinated (2 and 3) high-spin cobalt(II) ions with distorted octahedral (1) and tetrahedral (2 and 3) environments occur therein with ferro- (1) and antiferromagnetic (2 and 3) interactions between the magnetic centers. Interestingly, 3 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with T c = 7.5 K. The preparation of 1−3 together with their X-ray structures and magnetic investigation as a function of the temperature are the subject of this paper.

Curiously, six- (1) and four-coordinated (2 and 3) high-spin cobalt(II) ions with distorted octahedral (1) and tetrahedral (2 and 3) environments occur therein with ferro- (1) and antiferromagnetic (2 and 3) interactions between the magnetic centers. Interestingly, 3 is a spin canted antiferromagnet with T c = 7.5 K. The preparation of 1-3 together with their X-ray structures and magnetic investigation as a function of the temperature are the subject of this paper.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents used in the syntheses of 1−3 were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with an EA 1108 CHNS/0 automatic analyzer. IR spectrum of 1 (4000−400 cm-1) was recorded on Bruker IF S55 spectrophotometer with the sample prepared as a KBr pellet.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Reagents and solvents used in the syntheses of 1-3 were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with an EA 1108 CHNS/0 automatic analyzer. IR spectrum of 1 (4000-400 cm-1) was recorded on Bruker IF S55 spectrophotometer with the sample prepared as a KBr pellet.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (5 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol) was poured dropwise into an aqueous solution (8 mL) of H2phda (0.097 g, 0.5 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon linear, and it was heated at 75 °C during 48 h. X-ray quality crystals of 1 as pink plates were obtained after cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H12CoO6 (1): C, 41.83; H, 4.21%. Found: C, 41.81; H, 4.18%. The IR spectrum of 1 shows a broad and intense peak at 3400 cm−1 (antisymmetric and symmetric OH stretching) which is consistent with the presence of coordinated water. The presence of phda accounts for a strong peak at 1580 cm−1 (νasCOO), and medium intensities at 1437 and 1367 cm−1 (νsCOO), 813 and 738 cm−1 (δOCO).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complexes

[Co(H2O)2(phda)] n  (1)

An aqueous solution (5 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol) was poured dropwise into an aqueous solution (8 mL) of H2phda (0.097 g, 0.5 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon linear, and it was heated at 75 °C during 48 h. X-ray quality crystals of 1 as pink plates were obtained after cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H12CoO6 (1): C, 41.83; H, 4.21%. Found: C, 41.81; H, 4.18%. The IR spectrum of 1 shows a broad and intense peak at 3400 cm-1 (antisymmetric and symmetric OH stretching) which is consistent with the presence of coordinated water. The presence of phda accounts for a strong peak at 1580 cm-1 (νasCOO), and medium intensities at 1437 and 1367 cm-1 (νsCOO), 813 and 738 cm-1 (δOCO).

elements.content: An aqueous solution (8 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.250 g, 1 mmol) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (15 mL) containing H2phda (0.194 g, 1 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 150 °C during 96 h. X-ray quality crystals of 2 as purple prisms were obtained after a fast cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H8CoO4 (2): C, 47.83; H, 3.21%. Found: C, 47.84; H, 3.19%. The IR spectrum of 2 exhibits strong peaks at 1565 (νasOCO) and 1449 and 1364 cm−1 (νsOCO) and medium intensity absorptions at 795 and 747 cm−1 (δOCO).
elements.clean_text:
[Co(phda)] n  (2)

An aqueous solution (8 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.250 g, 1 mmol) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (15 mL) containing H2phda (0.194 g, 1 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 150 °C during 96 h. X-ray quality crystals of 2 as purple prisms were obtained after a fast cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H8CoO4 (2): C, 47.83; H, 3.21%. Found: C, 47.84; H, 3.19%. The IR spectrum of 2 exhibits strong peaks at 1565 (νasOCO) and 1449 and 1364 cm-1 (νsOCO) and medium intensity absorptions at 795 and 747 cm-1 (δOCO).

elements.content: NaOH (0.80 g, 2 mmol) dissolved in distilled water (ca. 10 mL) was added to an aqueous solution (15 mL) of H2chda (0.200 g, 1 mmol). An aqueous solution (8 mL) of CoCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was added dropwise to the previous one under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 170 °C during 96 h. Violet-pink plate-shape crystals of 3 were obtained after a fast cooling. The final product was washed with water and methanol and dried in air (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C20H28Co2O8 (3): C, 46.71; H, 5.49%. Found: C, 46.78; H, 5.46%. The IR of 3 exhibits characteristic bands for 1,1-cyclohexanediacetate. Strong absorption peaks at 1546 and 1423 cm−1 are assigned to νasOCO and νsOCO stretching vibrations of bidentate/bridging carboxylate groups.
elements.clean_text:
[Co(chda)] n  (3)

NaOH (0.80 g, 2 mmol) dissolved in distilled water (ca. 10 mL) was added to an aqueous solution (15 mL) of H2chda (0.200 g, 1 mmol). An aqueous solution (8 mL) of CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was added dropwise to the previous one under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 170 °C during 96 h. Violet-pink plate-shape crystals of 3 were obtained after a fast cooling. The final product was washed with water and methanol and dried in air (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C20H28Co2O8 (3): C, 46.71; H, 5.49%. Found: C, 46.78; H, 5.46%. The IR of 3 exhibits characteristic bands for 1,1-cyclohexanediacetate. Strong absorption peaks at 1546 and 1423 cm-1 are assigned to νasOCO and νsOCO stretching vibrations of bidentate/bridging carboxylate groups.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data sets were collected at 293(2) K (1−3) on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (0.71073 Å). Orientation matrix and lattice parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of the reflections obtained by a θ−χ scan (Dirac/lsq method). Data collection and data reduction of 1−3 were done with the COLLECT and EVALCCD programs. All the measured independent reflections were used in the analysis. The structures of 1−3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using SHELXL97. The hydrogen atoms of 1−3 (except those of the water molecules) were positioned geometrically and refined with a riding model. The structures of 1−3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. The hydrogen atoms in 1 and 2 were located in the calculated positions using the riding model (except those of the water molecules). For compound 1, the hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. The chda2− ligand in 3 is disordered into two different positions which were refined with coupled occupation factors, leading to sof values of 0.502(11) and 0.498(11) for each conformation. Within each of these positions of the chda2− ligand, the cyclohexyl groups have been encountered in two different conformations both refined with 0.5 occupation factor because they were generated by an 2-fold rotation axis. The location of the hydrogen atoms in 3 was precluded because of the high disorder of this structure. Although the cell parameters and the high symmetry of this disorder suggested the possibility to solve the structure in a different crystal system, such as the tetragonal one, the solutions obtained after thoroughly testing were not satisfactory.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination and Refinement

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data sets were collected at 293(2) K (1-3) on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (0.71073 Å). Orientation matrix and lattice parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of the reflections obtained by a θ-χ scan (Dirac/lsq method). Data collection and data reduction of 1-3 were done with the COLLECT and EVALCCD programs. All the measured independent reflections were used in the analysis. The structures of 1-3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using SHELXL97. The hydrogen atoms of 1-3 (except those of the water molecules) were positioned geometrically and refined with a riding model. The structures of 1-3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. The hydrogen atoms in 1 and 2 were located in the calculated positions using the riding model (except those of the water molecules). For compound 1, the hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. The chda2- ligand in 3 is disordered into two different positions which were refined with coupled occupation factors, leading to sof values of 0.502(11) and 0.498(11) for each conformation. Within each of these positions of the chda2- ligand, the cyclohexyl groups have been encountered in two different conformations both refined with 0.5 occupation factor because they were generated by an 2-fold rotation axis. The location of the hydrogen atoms in 3 was precluded because of the high disorder of this structure. Although the cell parameters and the high symmetry of this disorder suggested the possibility to solve the structure in a different crystal system, such as the tetragonal one, the solutions obtained after thoroughly testing were not satisfactory.

elements.content: The final geometrical calculations and the graphical manipulations were carried out with PARST97, PLATON, and DIAMOND programs. Their crystallographic data and the details of the refinements have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference nos. 723126, 723127, and 723128, respectively. They are reported in a condensed form in Table .

Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1−3 were carried out in the temperature range 1.9−300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under different applied magnetic field ranged from 50 G to 1 T. The magnetization measurements were performed at 2.0 K in the field range ±5 T. Corrections for the diamagnetic contribution of the constituent atoms and for the magnetization of the sample holder were done.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterizations

Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1-3 were carried out in the temperature range 1.9-300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under different applied magnetic field ranged from 50 G to 1 T. The magnetization measurements were performed at 2.0 K in the field range ±5 T. Corrections for the diamagnetic contribution of the constituent atoms and for the magnetization of the sample holder were done.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

The structures of the compounds 1-3 have been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Selected bond distances and angles together with the hydrogen bonds are listed in Tables  (1),  (2), and  (3).

The structure of 1 is made up of (4,4)-rectangular layers parallel to the ab plane, with the [Co(1)(H2O)2]2+ cations as 4-fold nodes connected through anti-syn carboxylate bridges from the fully deprotonated phda2− groups (Figure , right). Each layer is connected to its two adjacent ones through the skeleton of the phda2− ligand, giving rise to a 3D multilayered structure based on alternative stacking of (4,4) sheets pillared by the phenyl rings from the phenylenedicarboxylate ligands (Figure , left). Hydrogen bonding, involving the coordinated water molecules and oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups, contributes to the stabilization of the whole structure (see end Table ).

elements.content: The crystallographically independent cobalt atom [Co(1)] is located on an inversion center (Figure ), and it is six-coordinated, in a slightly elongated octahedral environment, with geometric values ϕ and s/h of 59.28° and 1.23 (ideal values ϕ = 60° and s/h = 1.22). The equatorial plane of Co(1) is built up by two water molecules and two carboxylate-oxygen atoms [O(1), O(1w), O(1) a-1 and O(1w) a-1; (a-1) = 1−x, −y, 1−z] whereas the axial positions are filled by another two carboxylate-oxygen atoms [O(2) b-1 and O(2) c-1; (b-1) = −0.5+x, 0.5−y, z and (c-1) = 1.5−x, −0.5+y, 1−z]. The mean value of the equatorial Co−O bond distance is 2.089(2) Å. This value is somewhat shorter than the average Co−O axial bond length [2.122(2) Å]. Each cobalt atom is connected to other four through four carboxylate groups that exhibit the anti-syn bridging conformation, giving rise to a (4,4) rectangular grid. These carboxylate groups act as connectors between equatorial and axial sites of each cobalt atom. Along each Co−O−C−O−Co pathway, the adjacent octahedra are tilted by 74.18°. This particular conformation is important to understand the ferromagnetic coupling observed in 1 (see below). The cobalt−cobalt separation through the anti-syn carboxylate bridge is 5.3164(4) Å [Co(1)···Co(1) e-1; (e-1) = 1.5−x, 0.5+y, 1−z], a value which is much smaller than the shortest separation between the metal atoms from two adjacent layers which are connected through the skeleton of the phda2− group [10.3667(7) Å for Co(1)···Co(1) d-1; (d-1) = 0.5−x, 0.5+y, −z].

elements.content: Each phda2− ligand in 1 is centrosymmetric, the inversion center being located in the middle of the phenyl ring. It adopts a tetrakis-monodentate coordination mode through its four carboxylate-oxygens: O(1) to Co(1), O(2) to Co(1) e-1 and the corresponding symmetry-related atoms (Figure ). The phda2− group acts as a connector between adjacent (4,4) rectangular layers. Three geometrical parameters (noted θ, ψ, and φ in Scheme are used in the literature to describe the distortion degree of the phda2− ligand: θ accounts for the bending in the center of the anion with the two carboxylate groups remaining coplanar, ψ represents the bending of the carboxylate groups toward each other, and φ is the relative twisting of the planes of two carboxylate groups. The θ, ψ, and φ, in the case of 1 are 180°, 180°, and 0°, respectively, values which are in agreement with those reported for other phda-containing metal complexes. The average value of the C−O bond lengths of the coordinated carboxylate-oxygen atoms is 1.277(2) Å. The internal C−C−C angles within the benzene ring at the substituted carbon atoms [117.7(2)°] are slightly smaller than those at the non-substituted ones [120.9(2)°], as expected.

We would like to finish this structural description of 1 with a brief comment on the structural similarities between 1 and the previously reported complex of formula [Co(H2O)2(OOCCH2OC6H5)2] n (C6H5OCH2COOH = phenoxyacetic acid). This compound exhibits a square grid arrangement of cobalt(II) ions linked through anti-syn carboxylate bridges similar to that of 1, but the layers in that compound are well separated from each other by the pendant phenyl rings, the shortest interlayer cobalt−cobalt separation being 16.9152(4) Å. The cobalt(II) is surrounded by two trans-coordinated water molecules and four carboxylate oxygen atoms building a somewhat elongated octahedral environment around the metal atom, as in 1. The tilting between adjacent octahedra in the phenoxyacetate compound is 41.80°, a value which is slightly different from that observed in 1.

elements.content: The structure of 2 resembles that of 1 but the (4,4) rectangular-grid layers in 2 contain tetrahedral CoO4 chromophores, anti-syn carboxylate bridges from the phda2− ligand linking each cobalt atom, which acts as a 4-fold node. The (4,4) layers grow in the ab plane, and they are pillared along the c axis through the skeleton of two crystallographically independent phenylenediacetate ligands, building two sets of organic pillars, one above and one below each (4,4) network. The resulting 3D structure is based on a regular stacking which follows the ABCDABCD sequence, A and C being the inorganic and B and C the organic sheets. (Figure ).

elements.content: One crystallographically independent cobalt atom [Co(1)] occurs in 2, and it is four-coordinated in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment (see Table and Figure ). The mean Co−O bond distance is 1.958(2) Å, a value which is slightly shorter than those observed for the octahedral surrounding of the cobalt(II) ion in 1 [ca. 2.110(2) Å]. As in 1, each cobalt atom in 2 is connected to other four metal atoms through four carboxylate bridges in the anti-syn conformation, giving rise to a (4,4) rectangular grid which grows in the ab plane. The tetrahedral Co(1)O4 groups are tilted by 35.5° with respect to each other along the a-axis [angle calculated between two adjacent planes built up by O(3)−Co(1)−O(4) b-2], this movement following an ABAB sequence (left/right). There is no significant twisting along the b-axis. The values of the cobalt−cobalt separations through the anti-syn carboxylate bridges are 4.8526(6) and 4.8841(5) Å across the O(3)−C(10)−O(4) and O(1)−C(5)−O(2) set of atoms, respectively. These values roughly correspond to the a and b crystallographic directions. The shortest separation between the cobalt atoms of two adjacent layers linked through the skeleton of the phda2− ligand is 9.6520(6) Å, a value which is considerably much longer than those observed for the intralayer metal−metal separations.

elements.content: Two crystallographically independent phda2− ligands occur in 2, and both are generated by an inversion center which is located in the middle of the phenyl rings. They adopt a tetrakis-monodentate coordination mode, similar to 1, through the O(1), O(2), O(3), and O(4) atoms toward Co(1), Co(1) a-2, Co(1), and Co(1) c-2, respectively [symmetry code: (a-2) = x, y−1, z and (c-2) = x+0.5, 1.5−y, z], together with those symmetry-related (see Figure ). The values of the θ, ψ, and φ parameters for both (phda)2− groups in 2 are the same than those observed in 1. The average C−O bond length is 1.256(3) Å, a value which agrees very well with that observed in 1. As expected, also the internal angles within the phenyl ring for the substituted carbon atoms are slightly smaller than those at the non-substituted ones [mean values 118.2(3) and 121.1(2)°, respectively].

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 is similar to that of 1, the main difference concerning the cobalt(II) environment, octahedral in 1 with the inclusion of two water molecules but tetrahedral in 2. Interestingly, the c unit cell parameter in 2 is twice longer than in 1. This is due to the occurrence of two crystallographically independent phda2− ligands in 2 with two different layers of organic pillars, which also accounts for the two slightly different values of the shortest Co···Co separation through the two different organic layers in 2 [the distances being 9.6520(6) and 10.6678(6) Å].

elements.content: As far as we know, only two previous examples of layers of tetrahedrally coordinated cobalt(II) ions have been reported, both of them containing dicarboxylate ligands, namely, {Co[O2C(CH2)5CO2]} n and {Co[O2C(CH2)3CO2]} n [HO2C(CH2) n CO2H = pimelic (n = 5) and glutaric (n = 3) acids]. Both compounds exhibit a square grid arrangement of cobalt(II) ions linked through anti-syn carboxylate bridges. The Co(II) ions are surrounded by four carboxylate-oxygen atoms in a somewhat distorted tetrahedral environment. The values of the tilting between adjacent tetrahedral are 40.4° and 44.4° for the pimelate and glutarate complexes, respectively (calculated as for 1). They are very close to those observed in 2. The resulting 3D structure is, as occurs in 2, also based on a regular stacking of inorganic (A and C) and organic sheets (B and D), which follow the ABCDABCD sequence, the two different interlayer cobalt−cobalt separations being 10.143(5) and 10.575(5) Å (pimelate complex) and 8.427(2) and 8.75(2) Å (glutarate compound).

The Co(II) ions are surrounded by four carboxylate-oxygen atoms in a somewhat distorted tetrahedral environment. The values of the tilting between adjacent tetrahedral are 40.4° and 44.4° for the pimelate and glutarate complexes, respectively (calculated as for 1). They are very close to those observed in 2. The resulting 3D structure is, as occurs in 2, also based on a regular stacking of inorganic (A and C) and organic sheets (B and D), which follow the ABCDABCD sequence, the two different interlayer cobalt-cobalt separations being 10.143(5) and 10.575(5) Å (pimelate complex) and 8.427(2) and 8.75(2) Å (glutarate compound).

elements.content: The structure of 3 is built up from corrugated (4,4) square grid layers of cobalt atoms which act as 4-fold nodes being connected through anti-syn carboxylate bridges from the fully deprotonated chda2− ligand. These layers grow in the ab plane, and they are separated from each other along the c direction by the cyclohexyl groups of the chda2− ligands which act as a hydrophobic barrier between the inorganic sheets (Figure ). There are two disordered positions for each dicarboxylate ligand and then, multiple scenarios are envisaged with the A and B conformations being randomly distributed within the crystal (Figure ). This situation does not alter the overall structure described above but the local distortion at the chda2− ligand and at the cobalt environment.

elements.content: One crystallographically independent cobalt atom [Co(1)] occurs in 3, laying on a 2-fold rotation axis. As in 2, each cobalt atom in 3 is four-coordinated in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment, regardless of the A or B conformation of the dicarboxylate ligand. The mean value of the Co−O bond distance is 1.969(7) Å (see Table ), a value which agrees with that observed in 3. The position of the cobalt ions is fixed whatever the ligand conformation was. The Co···Co separation through the anti-syn carboxylate bridge is 4.6806(6) Å, and the angle among three-adjacent cobalt atoms is 143.75° (which defines the corrugation of the layer). The tetrahedral CoO4 units in 3 are twisted as observed in 2, with a tilt angle of 16.20°. The shortest interlayer cobalt−cobalt separation is 12.932(2) Å, a value which is much longer than the intralayer one.

The mean value of the Co-O bond distance is 1.969(7) Å (see Table ), a value which agrees with that observed in 3. The position of the cobalt ions is fixed whatever the ligand conformation was. The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation through the anti-syn carboxylate bridge is 4.6806(6) Å, and the angle among three-adjacent cobalt atoms is 143.75° (which defines the corrugation of the layer). The tetrahedral CoO4 units in 3 are twisted as observed in 2, with a tilt angle of 16.20°. The shortest interlayer cobalt-cobalt separation is 12.932(2) Å, a value which is much longer than the intralayer one.

elements.content: One crystallographically independent chda2− ligand occurs in 3. It is disordered into two different conformations, A and B [see Figure (left)], with occupation factors of 0.502(11) and 0.498(11), respectively. Within each conformation, the cyclohexyl group is disordered into two positions of equal occupation since they are generated by a 2-fold rotation axis which corresponds to the vector connecting the C(1) carbon atom of the cyclohexyl ring and the cobalt atom Co(1), exhibiting a chair conformation. The chda2− group simultaneously adopts bidentate [through O(1) and O(1) a-3 chelating Co(1) the angle subtended at the cobalt atom being 111.45(14)°] and bis-monodentate [through O(2A-B) toward Co(1) b-3 and O(2A-B) c-3 toward Co(1) d-3] coordination modes [symmetry code: (b-3) = x−0.5,−y,0.5−z; (c-3) = 1−x, 0.5+y, 0.5−z; (d-3) = x+0.5,1−y,0.5−z]. The eight-member chelate ring formed by the bidentate coordination has been observed in the mononuclear manganese(II) complex [Mn(phen)(H2O)2(chda)]·3H2O (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) which is the only previously reported chda-containing coordination compound.

Within each conformation, the cyclohexyl group is disordered into two positions of equal occupation since they are generated by a 2-fold rotation axis which corresponds to the vector connecting the C(1) carbon atom of the cyclohexyl ring and the cobalt atom Co(1), exhibiting a chair conformation. The chda2- group simultaneously adopts bidentate [through O(1) and O(1) a-3 chelating Co(1) the angle subtended at the cobalt atom being 111.45(14)°] and bis-monodentate [through O(2A-B) toward Co(1) b-3 and O(2A-B) c-3 toward Co(1) d-3] coordination modes [symmetry code: (b-3) = x-0.5,-y,0.5-z; (c-3) = 1-x, 0.5+y, 0.5-z; (d-3) = x+0.5,1-y,0.5-z]. The eight-member chelate ring formed by the bidentate coordination has been observed in the mononuclear manganese(II) complex [Mn(phen)(H2O)2(chda)]⋅3H2O (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) which is the only previously reported chda-containing coordination compound.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 in the form of the χM T product against T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] are shown in Figure . χM T smoothly decreases when cooling from room temperature [2.95 cm3 mol−1 K at 295 K (μeff = 4.85 μB)] to reach a minimum at 30 K (ca. 2.49 cm3 mol−1 K), and it increases sharply at lower temperatures to attain a value of 12.36 cm3 mol−1 K at 1.9 K (under an applied magnetic field of 250 G). The decrease of χM T in the high temperature range is due to the depopulation of the high energy Kramers doublets (spin−orbit coupling effects) as expected for six coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) complexes. The increase of χM T in the low temperature region is due to a ferromagnetic exchange interaction between the Co(II) ions. This is supported by the fact that the value of χM T at the minimum (2.49 cm3 mol−1 K) is well above that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion (1.73 cm3 mol−1 K for a S eff = 1/2 with g ≈ 4.3). The lack of out-of-phase signal in the ac susceptibility down to 1.9 K precludes any magnetic ordering above this temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compound 1 

The magnetic properties of 1 in the form of the χM T product against T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] are shown in Figure . χM T smoothly decreases when cooling from room temperature [2.95 cm3 mol-1 K at 295 K (μeff = 4.85 μB)] to reach a minimum at 30 K (ca. 2.49 cm3 mol-1 K), and it increases sharply at lower temperatures to attain a value of 12.36 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K (under an applied magnetic field of 250 G). The decrease of χM T in the high temperature range is due to the depopulation of the high energy Kramers doublets (spin-orbit coupling effects) as expected for six coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) complexes. The increase of χM T in the low temperature region is due to a ferromagnetic exchange interaction between the Co(II) ions. This is supported by the fact that the value of χM T at the minimum (2.49 cm3 mol-1 K) is well above that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion (1.73 cm3 mol-1 K for a S eff = 1/2 with g ~ 4.3). The lack of out-of-phase signal in the ac susceptibility down to 1.9 K precludes any magnetic ordering above this temperature.

elements.content: When the large metal−metal separation through the skeleton of the ligand and the lack of exchange coupling between Co(II) ions in previous benzene-containing ligands as bta-bridged cobalt(II) complexes (H4bta=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) are considered, the magnetic behavior of 1 would correspond to the (4,4) rectangular-grid layers of cobalt(II) ions linked through anti-syn carboxylate groups. The ferromagnetic coupling involved in 1 is observed at low temperatures (T < 29 K in Figure ), just in the region where the ground-state Kramers doublet is the only populated state. This ground state can be treated as an effective spin doublet S eff = 1/2 with a Landé factor g o = (10 +2α)/3.

This ground state can be treated as an effective spin doublet S eff = 1/2 with a Landé factor g o = (10 +2α)/3.

elements.content: To determine the value of the exchange interaction in 1 in the whole temperature range, we have used an approach that we have reported recently. It is based on a perturbation model where the magnetic coupling only operates between the ground Kramers doublets which are considered as effective spins S eff = 1/2. The magnetic interactions in the excited doublets are neglected and thus, their magnetic properties are considered as those of the magnetically isolated ions. The contribution of these excited doublets to the magnetic properties on the ground one is taken into account by a second-order perturbation theory. This introduces a dependence on J, λ, Δ, and α in the Landé factor of the ground doublet (g 0). J is the isotropic exchange interaction, λ is the spin−orbit coupling, α is the orbital reduction factor [defined as α = kA, where k considers the reduction of the spin−orbit coupling because of covalency and A is a measure of the crystal-field strength and it takes into account the admixture of the upper 4T1g(4P) state into the 4T1g(4F) ground state], and Δ is the energy gap between the singlet 4A2 and doublet 4E levels because of the splitting of the orbital triplet 4T1g ground state under an axial distortion. All these effects are incorporated into a function named G(T,J) which replaces the value of the g 0 Landé factor of the ground Kramers doublet. This approach is valid in the limit of the weak magnetic coupling as compared to the spin−orbit coupling, |J/λ| < 0.1, and it allows the analysis of the magnetic data of high-spin Co(II) compounds in the whole temperature range. Following this approach, the Co(II) ions can be treated as effective spin doublets (S eff = 1/2) which are related with the real spins (S = 3/2) by S eff = (3/5)S. For that, the value of g 0 Landé factor of the ground Kramers doublet is substituted by the G(T,J) function, which is calculated as described.

The theoretical curve (solid line in Figure ) reproduces quite well the magnetic data in the temperature range 5−300 K. elements.content: The intralayer ferromagnetic coupling in 1 (J = +1.2 cm−1) is in agreement with the well-known ability of the anti-syn carboxylate bridge to mediate weak ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions, features which have been substantiated by density functional theory (DFT) type calculations for dinuclear Cu(II) complexes. However, magneto-structural studies on six-coordinated cobalt(II) complexes with the anti-syn carboxylate as a bridge are scarce. Examples of weak ferro- [the layered compound [Co(H2O)2(OOCCH2OC6H5)2] n 21 with J = +0.16 cm−1] and antiferromagnetic couplings [the 3D compound [Co2(bta)(H2O)4] n ·2nH2O with J = −0.06 cm−1] are known. The paucity of these data precludes us to go further in our discussion on the magnetic coupling of 1.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 2 in the form of the χM T product against T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] are shown in Figure . At room temperature, χM T is equal to 2.59 cm3 mol−1 K [μeff per Co(II) = 4.26 μB], a value which lies in the lower limit of the range observed for tetrahedral Co(II) complexes [μeff varying between 4.26 and 4.66 μB with the Co(II) in a 4A2 ground state]. Upon cooling, χM T continuously decreases to reach a value of 0.15 cm3 mol−1 K at 1.9 K. A maximum of the magnetic susceptibility occurs at 9.5 K, indicating the existence of an antiferromagnetic coupling in 2.

elements.content: On the basis of the lack of a significant magnetic coupling between the cobalt(II) ions of 2 through the extended phda2− bridge, most likely the exchange pathway in this compound is provided by anti-syn carboxylate bridges within each square layer of cobalt atoms. Consequently, we have treated the magnetic data of 2 through the Lines expression for a square grid of interacting spin quartets [eq ] χ M = N β 2 g 2 / | J | { 3 Θ + Σ n = 1 − 6 C n / Θ n − 1 } − 1 where Θ = 4kT/15|J|, C 1 = 4, C 2 = 1.600, C 3 = 0.304, C 4 = 0.249, C 5 = 0.132, and C 6 = 0.013. Because of the unavailability of a theoretical expression including both the magnetic coupling and the zero field splitting for the square lattice of tetrahedral Co(II) ions, the fit was performed discarding this last parameter. Least-squares fit of the magnetic susceptibility data of 2 in the temperature range 5−300 K through eq leads to following best-fit parameters: J = −1.63 cm−1, g = 2.23, and R = 2.6 × 10−5 (R is the agreement factor defined as ∑ i [(χM)obsd,i − (χM)calcd,i ]2/∑ i [(χM)obsd,i ]2). The calculated curve reproduces well the magnetic data from room temperature until 5 K. The computed value of the Landé factor for 2 [g = 2.23] lies in the range of previous values for this parameter in other tetrahedral Co(II) species (ca. 2.2−2.4). Finally, the obtained antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 agrees with those observed in other layered systems of tetrahedral cobalt(II) ions with the carboxylate bridge in the anti-syn bridging mode.

elements.content: However, the χM versus T plot for 3 exhibits a fast increase below 8.0 K when the applied magnetic field is decreased from 1 T to 50 G (see inset of Figure ). This abrupt increase of χM T below 8 K is due to a magnetic phase transition related to a spin canting with a critical temperature T c = 7.5 K. Its occurrence is supported by the field-cooled and zero-field cooled magnetizations (inset Figure ), hysteresis loop and ac susceptibility measurements (Figure ). Upon cooling in a low field (H = 50 G), the magnetization of 1 exhibits a sharp transition below 8 K (Figure ) and then it approaches a saturation value of 135 cm3 mol−1 G (0.024 μB). This value is far away from that expected for a high-spin Co(II) ion, indicating the presence of a small canting angle (θ). From this saturation value, a canting angle of about 0.4° with θ = 2 sin−1(M c/2M s). M c is the saturation value at 50 G and M s = gS is the expected saturation magnetization if all the moments are ferromagnetically aligned (considering, g = 2.4 and S = 3/2, see below). The value of T c is taken here as the maxima observed for in-phase (χM′) and out-of-phase (χM′′) ac magnetic susceptibilities (see Figure ). The magnetic hysteresis loop is shown in Figure . The values of coercive field (H c ) and remnant magnetization (M r ) at 2.0 K are 800 G and 0.02 μB, respectively.

elements.content: The exchange pathway for the observed antiferromagnetic coupling within each magnetically isolated square layer of tetrahedral cobalt(II) ions in 3 is provided by the anti-syn carboxylato bridge. Consequently, we can analyze the magnetic data of 3 in the temperature range 8−300 K through eq . The best-fit parameters are: J = −1.72 cm−1, g = 2.40, and R = 2.9 × 10−5 (R is the agreement factor defined as ∑ i [(χM)obsd,i − (χM)calcd,i ]2/∑ i [(χM)obsd,i ]2). The calculated curve reproduces the magnetic data from room temperature down to 8 K. The value of the antiferromagnetic coupling in 3 is very close to that of 2 because of the identical exchange pathway between the tetrahedral cobalt(II) ions within each square layer in both compounds with shortest values of the intralayer cobalt−cobalt separation of ca. 4.87 (2) and 4.68 Å (3). The corrugated structure of each layer of cobalt atoms in 3, where the metal atoms are related by a 2-fold rotation axis in contrast to what occurs in 2 where intralayer inversion centers operate among the non-adjacent cobalt atoms, would account for the spin canting observed in 3.

elements.content: Three distinct layered or pillared-layered complexes have been identified in the hydrothermal reaction of Co(II) and 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid or 1,1-cyclohexanediacetic acid in aqueous media: a weak but significant ferromagnetic coupling is present in [Co(H2O)2(phda)] (1) whereas antiferromagnetic interactions govern the magnetic behavior in [Co(phda)] (2) and [Co(chda)] (3), the last one exhibiting a spin-canted structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three distinct layered or pillared-layered complexes have been identified in the hydrothermal reaction of Co(II) and 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid or 1,1-cyclohexanediacetic acid in aqueous media: a weak but significant ferromagnetic coupling is present in [Co(H2O)2(phda)] (1) whereas antiferromagnetic interactions govern the magnetic behavior in [Co(phda)] (2) and [Co(chda)] (3), the last one exhibiting a spin-canted structure.

elements.content: The examples presented here are clear cases for which we have demonstrated that small structural modifications may cause important differences in the magnetic behavior of similar systems. In compound 1, the tilt angle among the adjacent CoO6 polyhedra together with the fact of anti-syn carboxylate bridge is connecting equatorial and axial sites, causes a ferromagnetic coupling within the layers. Because of the lower symmetry of 3 with respect to that of 2, complex 3 exhibits a spin-canted structure with T c at about 7.5 K.

cln_elements.content:
An aqueous solution (5 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.125 g, 0.5 mmol) was poured dropwise into an aqueous solution (8 mL) of H2phda (0.097 g, 0.5 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon linear, and it was heated at 75 °C during 48 h. X-ray quality crystals of 1 as pink plates were obtained after cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H12CoO6 (1): C, 41.83; H, 4.21%. Found: C, 41.81; H, 4.18%. The IR spectrum of 1 shows a broad and intense peak at 3400 cm−1 (antisymmetric and symmetric OH stretching) which is consistent with the presence of coordinated water. The presence of phda accounts for a strong peak at 1580 cm−1 (νasCOO), and medium intensities at 1437 and 1367 cm−1 (νsCOO), 813 and 738 cm−1 (δOCO).

[Co(phda)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

An aqueous solution (8 mL) of cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.250 g, 1 mmol) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (15 mL) containing H2phda (0.194 g, 1 mmol) under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 150 °C during 96 h. X-ray quality crystals of 2 as purple prisms were obtained after a fast cooling (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C10H8CoO4 (2): C, 47.83; H, 3.21%. Found: C, 47.84; H, 3.19%. The IR spectrum of 2 exhibits strong peaks at 1565 (νasOCO) and 1449 and 1364 cm−1 (νsOCO) and medium intensity absorptions at 795 and 747 cm−1 (δOCO).

[Co(chda)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

NaOH (0.80 g, 2 mmol) dissolved in distilled water (ca. 10 mL) was added to an aqueous solution (15 mL) of H2chda (0.200 g, 1 mmol). An aqueous solution (8 mL) of CoCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was added dropwise to the previous one under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 45 mL stainless-steel reactor with a Teflon liner, and it was heated at 170 °C during 96 h. Violet-pink plate-shape crystals of 3 were obtained after a fast cooling. The final product was washed with water and methanol and dried in air (no additional product has been obtained). Anal. Calcd for C20H28Co2O8 (3): C, 46.71; H, 5.49%. Found: C, 46.78; H, 5.46%. The IR of 3 exhibits characteristic bands for 1,1-cyclohexanediacetate. Strong absorption peaks at 1546 and 1423 cm−1 are assigned to νasOCO and νsOCO stretching vibrations of bidentate/bridging carboxylate groups.

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic properties of 1 in the form of the χM T product against T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] are shown in Figure . χM T smoothly decreases when cooling from room temperature [2.95 cm3 mol−1 K at 295 K (μeff = 4.85 μB)] to reach a minimum at 30 K (ca. 2.49 cm3 mol−1 K), and it increases sharply at lower temperatures to attain a value of 12.36 cm3 mol−1 K at 1.9 K (under an applied magnetic field of 250 G). The decrease of χM T in the high temperature range is due to the depopulation of the high energy Kramers doublets (spin−orbit coupling effects) as expected for six coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) complexes. The increase of χM T in the low temperature region is due to a ferromagnetic exchange interaction between the Co(II) ions. This is supported by the fact that the value of χM T at the minimum (2.49 cm3 mol−1 K) is well above that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion (1.73 cm3 mol−1 K for a S eff = 1/2 with g ≈ 4.3). The lack of out-of-phase signal in the ac susceptibility down to 1.9 K precludes any magnetic ordering above this temperature.

Compound <bold>2</bold>

The magnetic properties of compound 2 in the form of the χM T product against T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] are shown in Figure . At room temperature, χM T is equal to 2.59 cm3 mol−1 K [μeff per Co(II) = 4.26 μB], a value which lies in the lower limit of the range observed for tetrahedral Co(II) complexes [μeff varying between 4.26 and 4.66 μB with the Co(II) in a 4A2 ground state]. Upon cooling, χM T continuously decreases to reach a value of 0.15 cm3 mol−1 K at 1.9 K. A maximum of the magnetic susceptibility occurs at 9.5 K, indicating the existence of an antiferromagnetic coupling in 2.

Compound <bold>3</bold>

The magnetic properties of 3 in the form of the χM and χM T against T plots [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per mol of Co(II) ions] under an applied magnetic dc field of 1 T are shown in Figure . This plot is very close to that observed for the previous compound: χM T continuously decreases from 2.59 cm3 mol−1 K at room temperature (μeff = 4.55 μB) to 0.13 cm3 mol−1 K at 1.9 K. A maximum of the magnetic susceptibility occurs at 10.5 K confirming the occurrence of a significant intralayer antiferromagnetic interaction between the tetrahedral cobalt(II) ions in 3, as observed for 2.
